topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Deploy the KVM Region Patch 1_2

body.p: This patch addresses a number of issues in the KVM region.

Note: You can use the Horizon UI to see if the patch has been deployed. Select the regionkvm, then click Admin, then System, and Inventory. Click the Patches table for the TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001_2.patch. Or use the CLI on the active KVM controller: sudo sw-patch query.
Important! If you have deployed HCG2.0_WR001_Patch001, you must remove this patch before proceeding. See .
body.section:
Download the patch
If you have not downloaded the patch, launch the Helion Distribution Network (HDN). You must obtain a user account on HDN in order to download these files. In a browser, navigate to Helion Download Network(HDN).
Click Sign In to log in using your account.
After signing in, click the Downloads link in the menu on the left side of the page.
Download the file and the associated checksum and signature files.
Verify the downloaded signature and the downloaded checksums.
Extract the compressed files until the TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001_2.patch, readme.txt and usecase.txt files are available.

section.title: Install the patch
section.p: If HCG2.0_WR001_Patch001 is not installed, use the following steps to install the patch.
Important! If you have deployed HCG2.0_WR001_Patch001, you must remove this patch before proceeding. See .

section.title: Patch the standby controller

ol.li:
SSH into active controller in the KVM region.
For example: controller-0
Create a directory for the patch, if not present:mkdir -p /tmp/patches
Copy the TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001_2.patch patch file to the /tmp/patches directory.
Execute the following command to upload the patch to the repository: sudo sw-patch upload /tmp/patches/TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001_2.patch

Execute the following command to check if the patch is available for installation:sudo sw-patch query
For example:
Execute the following command to check the current state of all the hosts:sudo sw-patch query-hosts
Execute the following commands to apply the patch:sudo sw-patch apply TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001_2.patch source /etc/nova/openrc

Execute the following command to patch and reboot the standby controller: system host-patch-reboot <controller-#>
For example if controller-1 is the standby controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-1
Wait until the standby controller comes up after patching.

Execute the following command to switch the active controller from the specified controller: system host-swact controller-#
For example, if the active controller is controller-0:system host-swact controller-0
This command makes controller-1 the active controller and makes controller-0 the standby.
Exit the SSH session.

section.p: Log onto the newly active controller and patch the standby controller.

ol.li:
SSH into the newly active controller.
For example: controller-1.
Execute the following command: source /etc/nova/openrc

Execute the following command to patch and reboot the standby controller: system host-patch-reboot <controller-#>
For example if controller-0 is the standby controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-0

section.p: From the active controller, perform the following steps:

ol.li: Execute the following command to patch and reboot the compute-0: system host-patch-reboot compute-0
Execute the following command to patch and reboot compute-1: system host-patch-reboot compute-1

section.title: Remove Patch001
section.p: If you have deployed HCG2.0_WR001_Patch001, use the following steps to remove that patch.
Note: You can refer to the KVM Region Administrator Guide for more information on removing patches.

ol.li:
SSH into active controller in the KVM region.
For example: controller-0

Execute the following command to determine if the patch was applied:
sudo sw-patch query If applied, you should see the patch state as Applied.
Execute the following command to remove the patch:sudo sw-patch remove HCG2.0_WR001_Patch001
If you execute another query command, the Patch State will be Partial-Remove.sudo sw-patch query
Execute the following commands to check the current state of all the hosts: sudo sw-patch query-hostsYour host Reboot Required state will be Yes. For example:

Execute the following command to reboot the stanby controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-#
For example if controller-1 is the standby controller:system host-patch-reboot controller-1
Wait until the standby controller comes up after patching.

Execute the following command to switch the active controller from the specified controller: system host-swact controller-#
For example, if the active controller is controller-0:system host-swact controller-0
This command makes controller-1 the active controller and makes controller-0 the standby.
Exit the SSH session.

section.p: Log onto the newly active controller and patch the standby controller.

ol.li:
SSH into the newly active controller:
For example: controller-1.
Execute the following command to patch and reboot the new standby controller: system host-patch-reboot <controller-#>
Execute the following command to patch and reboot the compute-0: system host-patch-reboot compute-0
Execute the following command to patch and reboot compute-1: system host-patch-reboot compute-1
Execute the following command to make sure all the nodes are unlocked and in the Available state: sudo sw-patch query-hosts
Execute the following command to remove Patch001 from the database: sw-patch delete TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001

Execute the following command to determine if the patch was deleted:
sudo sw-patch query The TS_HP_15_Custom_PATCH_0001 patch should not appear in the list.
